area_name: Dairy Queen Wall - Upper Left Side

content.description:
To the right of

Pat Adams Dihedral

is this steep arete. Five bolts lead up the arete. This climb is MUCH more difficult than currently rated, in part because I broke a crimp while trying it in January of '06. At the current time, the crux is probably a V7 boulder problem followed by a difficult perch move on a large horn and more thin face climbing. The climbing is very good and the position is spectacular.
content.protection:
At least five quickdraws. Beware the first clipping hold/stick clip the first bolt: a broken hold/fall would deposit the climber directly onto a yucca (or nolina; not sure which) and possibly off the ledge if the belayer is not anchored.

No anchor exists at the top save old slings around a bush/sapling: exercise extreme caution with the bush/sapling and maybe bring something else to leave up there. It is possible to walk off via a complicated route over the top and down and around the back of the formation. 5th class climbing/downclimbing/traversing is mandatory.
content.location:
This route is located a pitch off the ground; it starts on a ledge above

Leap Year Flake

, a good pitch in its own right. The formation is a good ways left of the "main" right section of the Dairy Queen Wall.

content.description: This is a fun medium grade (5.8) route if you want to get to the top of DQ wall after ticking off Leap Year Flake.  The route was a bit chossy relative to other climbs at J-Tree.
content.protection: The crack will take nuts and cams up to 2.5 ".
content.location:
From the top of

Leap Year Flake

move right and take the crack just to the right of Toxic Waltz Arete.

content.description:
This is another neglected classic which is found on the left side of the

Dairy Queen Wall

. Once at the base of the cliff climb the excellent

Leap Year Flake

or

Leap Erickson

as an approach pitch. Once atop these routes you'll be under a large overhang capping a right facing corner which is the route.

The undercling/layback just off the start is the crux, and after the first 30 feet of climbing, you have to go up and around the roof which is easier, but a bit scary. An excellent stopper placement is here. Excellent rock and convenient rap anchor. Toproping is out of the question due to the huge rope drag; someone will have to second the leader to clean the gear. Pulling the rope after the rap is a bit tricky, pull to the far left.
content.protection: Small to medium cams, one large stopper is really helpful on the slabby part of the crack above roof.

content.description: Tricky moves down low along the vague arête and then run it out as the angle kicks back.
content.protection: 3 bolts (3/8") and gear to 2.5 inches for the belay
content.location:
Located on the arête just left of the

Pat Adams Dihedral

.

content.description:
Climbs a prominent crack that slants up and right and ends just below the top of the formation.

Leap Year Flake

might be a good route to approach this.
content.protection:
Gear to 2.5", bolted anchor/rap (3/8") shared with

Brazier Food
content.location:
Starts up and right from the finish of

Leap Year Flake

and just right of

Tofutti

.

content.description:
Stem start between the corner and the fragile flake of

Brazier Food

and higher follow the crack to bolted anchors.
content.protection:
Gear to 2.5 inches, bolted anchor/rap shared with

Double Delight.
content.location:
Above and right of the finish for

Leap Year Flake

. Crack in a corner and left of a thin flake system.

content.description:
Delicately climb a very thin flake off the ledge to reach a decent crack about halfway up just right of

Double Delight

.
content.protection:
Gear to 2 inches, bolted anchor/rap (3/8") shared with

Double Delight
content.location:
Starts up and right from the finish of

Leap Year Flake

and just right of

Double Delight

.

pathTokens: Dairy Queen Wall - Upper Left Side
